heading: Formation And Promotion Of 10,000 Farmer Producer Organizations (Fpos) Operational Guidelines
summary: The operational guidelines aim to form and promote 10,000 Farmer Producer Organizations (FPOs) with a focus on providing broad services and activities. The guidelines outline the formation of FPOs and the identification of clusters, along with the roles of the National Project Management Agency (NPMA) and implementing agencies. Budgetary provisions, FPO management costs, and provisions for equity grant and credit guarantee facility are also detailed. Additionally, the guidelines emphasize training, capacity building, implementation, and monitoring mechanisms, as well as the evaluation of the scheme. An integrated portal and annexures are also included in the guidelines.

content: 1.1  To provide holistic and broad based supportive ecosystem to form new 10,000  FPOs to facilitate development of vibrant and sustainable income oriented farming and for overall socio-economic development and wellbeing of agrarian communities.   1.2  To enhance productivity through efficient, cost-effective and sustainable resource  use and realize higher returns through better liquidity and market linkages for their produce and become sustainable through collective action.  1.3  To provide handholding and support to new FPOs up to 5 years from the year of  creation in all aspects of management of FPO, inputs, production, processing  and value addition, market linkages, credit linkages and use of technology etc.  1.4 To provide effective capacity building to FPOs to develop agricultureentrepreneurship skills to become economically viable and self-sustaining beyond the period of support from government.
heading: 1.0 Aims And Objectives Of The Scheme
summary: The scheme aims to establish 10,000 FPOs to support income-oriented farming and the overall socio-economic development of agrarian communities. It also seeks to improve productivity, resource use efficiency, and market linkages for higher returns, while promoting sustainability through collective action. The scheme provides handholding and support to new FPOs for up to 5 years, covering various aspects such as management, production, processing, market linkages, credit, and technology utilization. Additionally, it focuses on capacity building to develop agricultural entrepreneurship skills, enabling FPOs to become economically viable and self-sustaining beyond government support.

content: FPO is a generic name, which means and includes farmer- producers'  organization incorporated/ registered either under Part IXA of Companies Act or under Co-operative Societies Act of the concerned States and  formed for the purpose of leveraging collectives through economies of scale in production and marketing of agricultural and allied sector.  However, FPOs registered under Cooperative Societies Act of the State (including Mutually Aided or Self-reliant Cooperative Societies Act by whatever name it is called) for the purpose of this  Scheme, is to be insulated from all kinds of interference including in election process and day today management through suitable provisioning in their Memorandum of Association and Bye-laws with a view to encourage healthy growth and development of FPO.
heading: 2.0 Farmer Producer Organization (Fpo)
summary: The Farmer Producer Organization (FPO) is a collective formed under the Companies Act or Co-operative Societies Act to enhance economies of scale in agricultural production and marketing. FPOs registered under the Cooperative Societies Act are to be protected from interference in their management and election processes. This insulation is aimed at promoting the healthy growth and development of FPOs.

content: The FPOs may provide and undertake following relevant major services and activities for their development as may be necessary:-   (i)  Supply quality production inputs like seed, fertilizer, pesticides and such other inputs at reasonably lower wholesale rates.  (ii)  Make available need based production and post-production machinery and equipment like cultivator, tiller, sprinkler set, combine harvester and such other machinery and equipment on custom hiring basis for members to reduce the per  unit production cost.  (iii)  Make available value addition like cleaning, assaying, sorting, grading, packing  and also farm level processing facilities at user charge basis on reasonably cheaper rate. Storage and transportation facilities may also be made available.  (iv) Undertake higher income generating activities like seed production, bee keeping,  mushroom cultivation etc.  (v)   Undertake aggregation of smaller lots of farmer-members' produce; add value to make them more marketable.  (vi) Facilitate market information about the produce for judicious decision in  production and marketing.  (vii) Facilitate logistics services such as storage, transportation, loading/un-loading  etc. on shared cost basis.   (viii)  Market the aggregated produce with better negotiation strength to the buyers  and in the marketing channels offering better and remunerative prices. heading: 3.0 Broad Services And Activities To Be Undertaken By Fpos
summary: FPOs can provide services like supplying production inputs at lower rates, offering machinery on a custom hiring basis, and providing value addition and processing facilities. They can also engage in income-generating activities like seed production and beekeeping, aggregate farmer-members' produce, and facilitate market information and logistics services. Additionally, FPOs can market the aggregated produce with better negotiation strength to secure better prices. These activities are part of a business plan for the development of FPOs in the medium and long term.

content: 4.1 Formation and promotion of FPO is based on Produce Cluster Area, which is  broadly defined as:  "Produce Cluster aerA" for purpose of FPO formation and management herein means a geographical area wherein agricultural and allied produce such as ltSytlthytS h produce of similar or of almost similar nature is grown / cultivated;  therefore, an FPO can be formed for leveraging economies of scale in production and marketing. This will also cover Organic Produce and Natural Farming.   4.2 Produce cluster area is to be identified with the input of District Level Monitoring    Committee (D-MC), State Level Consultative Committee (SLCC), other Ministries/Departments of Government of India and the States as well as with recommendations of Implementing Agencies with input from Cluster- Based Business Organization (CBBO) and suggestions of relevant Government of India Organizations.      4.3 CBBOs will undertake Feasibility Study in assigned clusters which will include the  following:  (i) **Diagnostic study including Baseline survey** to find out produce and socio- cultural similarity, existing gap and potential activity, interventions in terms of infrastructure, services, etc. required in the value chain of agricultural and horticultural produce including post-harvest management and marketing.
heading: Will Be The Hallmark Of Strong Business Growth For Fpo. 4.0 Strategy For Formation Of Fpo And Identification Of Cluster Area
summary: Formation and promotion of FPO is based on Produce Cluster Area, which is a geographical area where similar agricultural and allied produce is grown. This includes organic produce and natural farming, and aims to leverage economies of scale in production and marketing. The identification of produce cluster areas involves input from various committees, ministries, and organizations, as well as feasibility studies conducted by Cluster-Based Business Organizations (CBBOs). The feasibility studies include diagnostic studies and baseline surveys to identify produce and socio-cultural similarities, existing gaps, potential activities, and interventions needed in the value chain of agricultural and horticultural produce.

Farmer-members cohesively located with almost same interest are to be mobilized to form a group of 15-20 Members, calling the group as   Farmer Interest Group (FIG) or Self Help Group (SHG), Farmers Club (FC), Joint Liability Group (JLG) , Rythu Mitra Group. Such 20 or more groups from a produce cluster area or a village/ cluster of neighboring villages based on certain commonalities are to be put together to form an FPO with a minimum farmer-members size of 300 to be eligible under this scheme in plains while in Hilly and North Eastern regions, 7-8 are to be put together to form an FPO with a minimum farmer-members size of 100.
heading: Will Be The Hallmark Of Strong Business Growth For Fpo. 4.0 Strategy For Formation Of Fpo And Identification Of Cluster Area
summary: The baseline survey should identify the current farming situation and the farmers for aggregation. A prospective business plan is needed to establish a sustainable FPO. In plains, an FPO with a minimum of 300 farmer-members is eligible, while in North-Eastern and Hilly areas, a size of 100 is eligible. Farmer-members with similar interests should be mobilized to form groups, and these groups should be put together to form an FPO with a minimum size of 300 in plains and 100 in Hilly and North Eastern regions.

heading: Will Be The Hallmark Of Strong Business Growth For Fpo. 4.0 Strategy For Formation Of Fpo And Identification Of Cluster Area
summary: The strategy aims to include small, marginal, women, SC/ST farmers, and economically weaker categories as FPO members for effectiveness and inclusivity. Efforts will be made to achieve an average membership size of 500 farmers in plain areas and 200 farmers in hilly and North-Eastern regions for economic sustainability. The goal is to form an average of two FPOs in at least each of the potential 5,000 blocks, with efforts to cover all blocks in the country. FPOs can federate at district and state levels for processing, branding, marketing of produce, and trading of commodities to scale up for survivability and growth. The Department of Agriculture may revise the minimum membership norm per FPO based on experience or need, with the approval of the Union Agriculture Minister.

content: Based on their need, success and product, they can federate at the National level also to promote packaging/branding and domestic/international trading of quality produce. Such Federation may avail advisory of National Project Management Agency (NPMA) as well as will be eligible for Credit Guarantee facility under the Scheme to strengthen their activities relating to setting up of infrastructure and supply chain for value addition and marketing.    4.7 While adopting cluster-based approach for produce or produce mix, formation of  FPOs will also focus on "One District One Product" approach for development of product specialization, in case the focused agriculture produce has been declared for that district, whereby FPOs will be encouraged for promoting processing,  branding, marketing and export of the product for better value realization. There may be more than one cluster for one product in one district and a cluster also may  extend beyond a district. However, to be an FPO economically sustainable and  diversify risk & enhance returns, the FPO will also have additional product and service mix; so that there are enough activities and engagements with the members throughout the year.
heading: Will Be The Hallmark Of Strong Business Growth For Fpo. 4.0 Strategy For Formation Of Fpo And Identification Of Cluster Area
summary: FPOs can federate at the national level to promote packaging/branding and trading of quality produce, with the option to seek advisory services from the National Project Management Agency and access credit guarantee facilities. The formation of FPOs will focus on a cluster-based approach and "One District One Product" strategy to develop product specialization and promote processing, branding, marketing, and export for better value realization. FPOs are encouraged to diversify their product and service mix to ensure economic sustainability and mitigate risk while enhancing returns. Additionally, they will be eligible for support to strengthen infrastructure, supply chain, value addition, and marketing activities. Multiple clusters for one product in a district and clusters extending beyond a district are also possible.

content: Furthermore, FPOs can federate at district level, State level & National level for the product identified as per their requirement of processing,  branding and marketing.     4.8 Concerted efforts will be made to prioritize formation of FPOs in aspirational  districts through intense awareness programmes and making FPOs economically sustainable through adequate support, handholding, training & skill development. However, intensive efforts will be made to form & promote at least 15% of the  total targeted 10,000 FPOs (i.e. 1,500 FPOs) in next 5 years in aspirational districts with at least one FPO in each block of aspirational districts of the country for their development. In order to promote the forest and minor forest produce by the tribal communities, intensive efforts will be made by the implementing agencies to prioritize formation and promotion of FPOs in the notified tribal areas in the country.  The benefits of quality input, technology, credit and value addition and processing as well as better market access should reach the tribal community and North-East Region through the Scheme in co-operation with Tribal Affairs Ministry, DONER and North Eastern Council (NEC).
heading: Will Be The Hallmark Of Strong Business Growth For Fpo. 4.0 Strategy For Formation Of Fpo And Identification Of Cluster Area
summary: FPOs can federate at district, state, and national levels for processing, branding, and marketing, based on product requirements. The strategy aims to prioritize forming FPOs in aspirational districts through awareness programs and economic sustainability support. The goal is to establish and promote 1,500 FPOs in aspirational districts within the next 5 years, with at least one FPO in each block. Intensive efforts will focus on forming and promoting FPOs in notified tribal areas, particularly to benefit tribal communities and the North-East Region. The scheme will collaborate with Tribal Affairs Ministry, DONER, and North Eastern Council to provide quality input, technology, credit, value addition, and market access to these regions.

content: 5.1 At national level, a National Project Management Agency (NPMA) will be set up  by SFAC through transparent manner for providing overall project guidance, data maintenance through integrated portal and information management and monitoring. The NPMA will be equipped with the technical team with five categories of specialisation in Agriculture / Horticulture, Marketing and  Processing, Incubation Service Provider, IT/MIS and Law & Accounting to provide overall guidance at all India level.
heading: 5.0 National Project Management Agency (Npma)
summary: A National Project Management Agency (NPMA) will be established at the national level by SFAC to provide project guidance, data maintenance, and information management. The NPMA will have a technical team with expertise in Agriculture/Horticulture, Marketing and Processing, Incubation Service Provider, IT/MIS, and Law & Accounting to offer guidance at the all India level.

content: The NPMA will be expected to provide hand holding support and mentoring support to CBBOs, and need to have extensive experience in performing strategic roles, preferably in the agricultural domain at the national and state level. SFAC may, while formulating the criteria for selection of NPMA, take into account the appropriate qualifications and experience of requisite experts, relevant experience of organization/entity in guiding both companies and cooperative organizations as reasonably required for discharge of role envisaged for NPMA under the Scheme including the minimum net worth for suitability. The strength and experience may include strategic inputs around organizational  management, processing, value addition, marketing & market linkage in agriculture/horticulture, accounting & auditing, compliance issues, ICT & MIS experience, incubation services and providing project management support to central and state governments, transaction and post transaction management support, and qualification of experts proposed for the work. The period of engagement of NPMA is to be decided suitably.
heading: 5.2 Criteria For Identification Of Npma:
summary: The NPMA should provide hand holding and mentoring support to CBBOs and have extensive experience in strategic roles in the agricultural domain at the national and state level. SFAC will consider appropriate qualifications and experience of experts, relevant experience of the organization in guiding companies and cooperative organizations, and minimum net worth for suitability when formulating the criteria for NPMA selection. The NPMA's strength and experience should include strategic inputs in organizational management, processing, value addition, marketing, market linkage in agriculture/horticulture, accounting, auditing, compliance issues, ICT, MIS experience, incubation services, project management support to governments, transaction and post transaction management support, and qualification of experts. The period of engagement for NPMA will be decided accordingly.

content: The role of the NPMA shall*, inter alia,* include those given as under-   ÔÇ∑ Drawing contours of the program including structuring of clusters:-  NPMA would start the assignment by chalking out program with detailed SOPs for each stakeholder in the value chain. Identification of target value chains required would be steppingstone for development of the road map. Once the value chains are established, it defines clusters to be chosen for FPO formation. Here, NPMA would draft out detailed SOP for CBBO for further action. Value chain analysis would also identify both forward/backward linkage mechanism.    ÔÇ∑ Transaction Advisory for selection of CBBOs:-  NPMA would provide Transaction Advisory services to Implementing Agencies  (those who seek their support) for selection of CBBOs. After preparation of action plan for project execution, NPMA may assist Implementation Agencies in carrying out transaction for engagement of CBBOs for said clusters. Alternately, Implementing Agencies may carry out the selection process on their own. Such step requires delineating detailed scope, team requirement with relevant qualifications & experience.
heading: 5.3 Duties And Responsibilities Of Npma :
summary: The NPMA's duties include outlining the program and structuring clusters, identifying target value chains, and defining clusters for FPO formation. They also provide transaction advisory services to Implementing Agencies for the selection of CBBOs and may assist in carrying out transactions for engagement of CBBOs. Alternatively, Implementing Agencies may carry out the selection process on their own, requiring a detailed scope, team requirements, and relevant qualifications and experience.

content: ÔÇ∑ Post transaction support for effective project/programme implementation:-  After selecting CBBOs as per the requirements, NPMA will be responsible to support SFAC, NCDC & NABARD and other Implementing Agencies including State nominated Implementing Agencies in effective implementation and monitoring of the project execution.  Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) based monitoring of CBBOs would be conducted regularly by NPMA. NPMA in turn will appraise N-PMAFSC regarding the performance of CBBOs, formation of FPOs, handholding support provided by CBBOs etc. through detailed MIS submitted on monthly basis for which ICT based MIS Integrated Portal will also be developed. Further, NPMA may also handhold CBBOs in effective delivery of the project. NPMA should work in tandem with CBBOs and Professional Agencies, if any, and ensure that adequate support is extended to States of North-East and hilly  regions to offset deficiency in specialized manpower and expertise available in such areas including even extending support directly to FPOs/Federation of FPOs for their promotion wherever required. It will assist DAC&FW in formation and promotion of FPOs in the State(s) where there are unavailability of experts. It will also provide suitable professional advisory to existing FPOs who approach for advice.
heading: 5.3 Duties And Responsibilities Of Npma :
summary: NPMA is responsible for providing post-transaction support to ensure effective project implementation and monitoring, including conducting regular KPI-based monitoring of CBBOs and appraising N-PMAFSC on their performance. They will also develop an ICT-based MIS Integrated Portal for detailed MIS submission on a monthly basis and provide handholding support to CBBOs for project delivery. NPMA is expected to work closely with CBBOs and Professional Agencies, if any, to ensure adequate support is provided to states in North-East and hilly regions, including extending support directly to FPOs/Federation of FPOs. Additionally, NPMA will assist DAC&FW in forming and promoting FPOs in states where experts are unavailable and provide professional advisory to existing FPOs seeking advice.

content: It may also provide professional advisory to new FPOs being promoted by Value Chain Organisations under the Scheme when required. heading: 5.3 Duties And Responsibilities Of Npma :
summary: The NPMA provides professional advisory to new FPOs promoted by Value Chain Organisations and assists in structured interface with stakeholders like Ministries, Financial Institutions, and Training and Research & Development Institutions. It acts as an extended arm with specific output to N-PMAFSC while interacting with various stakeholders and helps to structure the approach, create outreach materials, and organize partnerships. The NPMA also functions as a national level data repository and maintains an integrated portal for FPOs, serving as a national platform for their data needs and digital maintenance. Additionally, it supports in the formulation of program and policy directions, creating knowledge for FPO formation and offering programmatic and policy suggestions.

content: NPMA will assist in formulation of such  suggestions, churned out from the project's learning; which has capability of  adding value to agri-business overall. heading: 5.3 Duties And Responsibilities Of Npma :
summary: NPMA will assist in formulating suggestions from project learning to add value to agri-business. It will facilitate policy orientation and advocacy at the national and state levels, identifying institutes and partnering with stakeholders for effective project implementation. content: 6.1 In order to form and promote FPOs in uniform and effective manner so as to  achieve the target of formation of 10,000 new FPOs in  5 years and to make the FPOs economically sustainable, tltyt hht    three Implementing Agencies, namely,  SFAC, NCDC and NABARD, shall be responsible to form and promote FPOs. 6.1.1 SFAC will form and promote those FPOs to be incorporated under Part IX A of Companies Act.  6.1.2 NCDC will form and promote those FPOs to be registered under any Cooperative Societies Act of the States.             6.1.3 NABARD will form and promote those FPOs which are registered either  under Part IX A of Companies Act or registered under any Co-operative Societies Act of States.  6.2 In addition to afore-stated three implementing agencies, if any State/Union  Territory is desirous to have its own implementing agency, State/UT may  approach DAC & FW with details about the State/UT, its agency, activities and experience of the agency etc., and DAC & FW will consider the proposal on experiences and existing manpower required for formation and promotion of FPOs in the region.
heading: 6.0 Implementing Agencies
summary: Three implementing agencies, SFAC, NCDC, and NABARD, are responsible for forming and promoting FPOs to achieve the target of 10,000 new FPOs in 5 years. SFAC will focus on FPOs incorporated under Part IX A of the Companies Act, while NCDC will work with FPOs registered under any Cooperative Societies Act of the States. NABARD will support FPOs registered under Part IX A of Companies Act or any Co-operative Societies Act of States. Additionally, states or union territories can establish their own implementing agencies by approaching DAC & FW with relevant details for consideration.

content: 6.3 DAC&FW may, in due course, identify and assign other additional Implementing  Agencies to cover various sectors and geographical locations to form 10,000  FPOs as per the need of the programme.    6.4 The Initial Implementing Agencies as well as the State level or any other  Implementing Agencies approved by DAC&FW shall also be supported.      6.5 Year-wise indicative target for Implementing Agencies- Considering the  Implementing Agencies' existence in the States/Regions/Districts/Produce Clusters, their human resource and also their area of specialization, targets are to be tentatively allocated by Project Management Advisory and Fund Sanctioning Committee (N-PMAFSC) in consultation with the Implementing Agencies. heading: 6.6 Duties And Responsibilities Of Implementing Agencies:
summary: Implementing Agencies are responsible for working closely with CBBOs to ensure the economic sustainability of FPOs and monitoring their activities. They will also oversee the regular data entry on the integrated portal and ensure interoperability with the national level Integrated Portal managed through NPMA. NABARD and NCDC will manage the Credit Guarantee Fund, while the Implementing Agencies, in consultation with DAC&FW, will develop rating tools for FPOs to assess their activity level and sustainability. Additionally, the Implementing Agencies will prepare an Annual Action Plan and submit it to DAC&FW for consideration by the Project Management Advisory and Fund Sanctioning Committee.

content: (vii) As assigned by DAC&FW/N-PMAFSC, Implementing Agency will coordinate  with concerned Value-Chain Organization(s) regarding stages of formation and promotion of FPOs by those organizations along with FPO management  cost & utilization of previous amount along with documentary proof from time to time as well as requirement of Equity Grant for channelizing their claim to  N-PMAFSC for payment. heading: 6.6 Duties And Responsibilities Of Implementing Agencies:
summary: Implementing agencies are responsible for coordinating with value-chain organizations regarding the formation and promotion of FPOs, as well as managing FPO management costs and providing documentary proof of fund utilization. They may create monitoring and data management units with prior approval to handle the increasing volume of FPOs, but must coordinate with NPMA for necessary input as a national level data repository.

content: 7.1 Implementing Agencies will set up Cluster- Based Business Organizations  (CBBOs) at the State/Cluster level to form and promote FPOs as per their  requirements; however, targets for produce clusters, full or part of the State or  region will be allocated by Project Management Advisory and Fund Sanctioning Committee (N-PMAFSC). The Implementing Agencies will apply due diligence to  ensure that professionally competent CBBOs are transparently engaged & have  experience in promotion and professional supports to FPOs.  a) In a State, based on geography, produce clusters, cropping pattern, etc.,  there may be one or more than one CBBO. Even one CBBO may serve more than one State as per requirement. However, CBBOs should be given work according to available human resources with them, their past turnover and work experience etc.  b) The CBBOs should be going concern with professional experience and  exposure in formation of FPOs in agriculture and allied sector and providing handholding support to them.  c) The CBBOs should be supported with five categories of specialists from the  domain of (i) Crop husbandry; (ii) Agri. marketing / Value addition and processing; (iii) Social mobilization; (iv) Law & Accounts; and (v) IT/MIS in agriculture & agriculture marketing.
heading: 7.0 Cluster- Based Business Organizations (Cbbos)
summary: Cluster-Based Business Organizations (CBBOs) will be set up by Implementing Agencies at the State/Cluster level to promote FPOs, with targets allocated by the Project Management Advisory and Fund Sanctioning Committee. The selection of CBBOs will involve due diligence to ensure their professional competence, transparency, and experience in supporting FPOs. Depending on factors like geography and cropping patterns, there may be one or more CBBOs in a State, and they may serve multiple States based on resource availability. CBBOs are expected to have professional experience in forming FPOs in the agriculture and allied sectors, and they should be supported by specialists in crop husbandry, agri-marketing, social mobilization, law & accounts, and IT/MIS in agriculture and agriculture marketing.

heading: 7.0 Cluster- Based Business Organizations (Cbbos),7.2 Criteria For Identification Of Cbbos:

summary: The performance of CBBOs in FPO projects is assessed in three stages. In the first six months, assessment is based on baseline survey, submitted reports, and FPO formation activities. In the second year, assessment criteria include equity grant availed by FPOs, statutory clearances obtained, business activities execution, awareness programs, exposure visits, equity grant and credit guarantee facility availed, and institutional training provided to CEOs/BoDs. heading: Implementing Agencies For Performance Assessment Of Cbbos-
summary: The performance of the CBBOs will be assessed over a five-year period, with specific criteria for each year. content: 10.1 Under the scheme, financial support to Farmer Producer Organization (FPO)      @ up to maximum of Rs. 18 lakh / FPO or actual, whichever is lesser is to be provided during three years from the year of formation. The financial support is not meant for reimbursing the entire administrative and management cost of FPO but it is to provide the financial support to the FPOs to the extent provided  to  make them sustainable and economically viable. Hence, the fourth year onwards of formation, the FPO has to manage their financial support from their own business activities. The indicative financial support broadly covers (i) the support for salary of its CEO/Manager (maximum up to Rs.25000/month) and Accountant (maximum up to Rs. 10000/month); (ii) one time registration cost(one time up to  maximum Rs. 40000 or actual whichever is lower); (iii) office rent (maximum up to Rs. 48,000/year); (iv) utility charges (electricity and telephone charges of office of FPO maximum up to Rs. 12000/year); (v) one-time cost for minor equipment (including furniture and fixture maximum up to Rs. 20,000); (vi) travel and meeting cost (maximum up to Rs.18,000/year); and (vii) misc. (cleaning, stationery etc. maximum up to Rs. 12,000/year).
heading: 10.0 Fpo Management Cost
summary: Financial support of up to Rs. 18 lakh or actual cost is provided to FPOs over three years, not meant to cover the entire administrative and management expenses but to ensure sustainability. From the fourth year onwards, FPOs are expected to manage their finances from their own business activities. The indicative financial support includes salary support for CEO/Manager and Accountant, one-time registration cost, office rent, utility charges, minor equipment cost, travel and meeting expenses, and miscellaneous expenses. The maximum support for CEO/Manager's salary is Rs. 25,000/month and for Accountant is Rs. 10,000/month. Additionally, one-time registration cost is up to Rs. 40,000 or actual, office rent is up to Rs. 48,000/year, and utility charges are up to Rs. 12,000/year.

content: Any expenditure of operations, management, working capital requirement and infrastructure development etc., over and above this, will be met by the FPOs from their financial resources.  10.2 FPO being organization of farmers, it does not become feasible for FPO itself to  professionally administer its activities and day to day business, therefore, FPO requires some professionally equipped Manager/CEO to administer its activities and day to day business with a sole objective to make FPO economically sustainable and farmers' benefiting agri-enterprise. Not only for business  development but the value of professional is immense in democratizing the FPOs and strengthening its governing system. To substantiate the fact, the most successful example is of dairy co-operative in India where professional managers have contributed immensely to make it a success. There are other so many examples which prove the absolute requirement of professional managers. The number of professional staff could depend on geographical spread of business operation, diversity of activities and volume of business. However, an FPO should have minimum a CEO/Manager and an Accountant. Accountant is required in FPO to look after its day to day accounting work. Based on requirement, FPO can engage other staff also.
heading: 10.0 Fpo Management Cost
summary: FPOs are responsible for covering their own operational, management, working capital, and infrastructure costs. Due to the complexity of their activities, FPOs require professionally equipped managers or CEOs to ensure economic sustainability and benefit for farmers. Professional management is crucial for business development, democratizing FPOs, and strengthening their governance. The success of dairy cooperatives in India highlights the significant contribution of professional managers. Depending on the scale and scope of operations, an FPO should have at least a CEO/Manager and an Accountant, with the possibility of engaging additional staff based on need.

content: 10.3 The CEO/Manager is to be appointed by the executive body of the FPO who  should be either graduate in agriculture / agriculture marketing / agri-business management or BBA or equivalent. heading: 10.0 Fpo Management Cost
summary: The CEO/Manager of the FPO should have a degree in agriculture, agriculture marketing, agri-business management, BBA, or equivalent, while locally available professionals with a diploma in related areas may also be considered. content: 11.1 Producer members' own equity supplemented by a matching Equity Grant from  Government, which is required to strengthen financial base of FPOs and help them to get credit from financial institutions for their projects and working capital requirements for business development. Equity Grant shall be in the form of matching grant upto Rs. 2,000 per farmer member of FPO subject to maximum limit of Rs. 15.00 lakh fixed per FPO. This Equity Grant is not in the form of government participation in equity, but only as a matching grant to the FPOs as  farmer members' equity. Therefore, Rs.1,500 crore with DAC&FW is proposed in the scheme to cover all the 10,000 FPOs, if maximum permissible equity is contributed to all 10,000 FPOs.  11.2 **Objectives of Equity Grant:** The objectives of Equity Grant are   to (i) enhance  viability and sustainability of FPOs; (ii) increase credit worthiness of FPOs; and  (iii) enhance shareholding of members to increase their ownership and participation in their FPO.  11.3 **Eligibility Criteria for FPOs:** An FPO fulfilling following criteria shall be eligible to  apply  for Equity Grant under the Scheme-    (i) It shall be a legal entity as per para 2  of this guidelines.
heading: 11.0 Provision For Equity Grant
summary: The Equity Grant program aims to strengthen the financial base of FPOs by providing a matching grant of up to Rs. 2,000 per farmer member, with a maximum limit of Rs. 15.00 lakh per FPO. This grant is not a form of government equity participation, but rather a matching grant to support farmer members' equity. The proposed budget of Rs. 1,500 crore is intended to cover all 10,000 FPOs, if the maximum permissible equity is contributed to each one. The objectives of the Equity Grant include enhancing the viability and sustainability of FPOs, increasing their credit worthiness, and boosting member ownership and participation. To be eligible for the Equity Grant, an FPO must be a legal entity as per the provided guidelines.

heading: 11.0 Provision For Equity Grant

No single member can hold more than 10% of the total equity of the FPO. A farmer can be a member of multiple FPOs but is eligible for the matching equity grant only once. The Board of Directors and Governing Body must have adequate representation of women farmer members, with at least one woman member, and there should be a duly constituted Management Committee responsible for the FPO's business.

content: 12.1 In order to ensure access of FPOs to credit from mainstream Banks and  Financial Institutions, there is a need to create a dedicated fund. The dedicated  Credit Guarantee Fund (CGF) will provide suitable credit guarantee cover to accelerate flow of institutional credit to FPOs by minimizing the risk of financial institutions for granting loan to FPOs so as to improve their financial ability to execute better business plans leading increased profits.
heading: 12.0 Credit Guarantee Facility
summary: A dedicated Credit Guarantee Fund (CGF) will be created to ensure FPOs' access to credit from mainstream banks and financial institutions. This fund aims to provide credit guarantee cover to accelerate the flow of institutional credit to FPOs, minimizing the risk for financial institutions when granting loans to FPOs. The goal is to improve the financial ability of FPOs to execute better business plans and ultimately increase profits.

content: The primary objective of CGF is providing a Credit Guarantee Cover to Eligible Lending Institution (ELI) to enable them to provide collateral free credit to FPOs by minimising their lending risks in respect of loans.(i)A dedicated Fund of up to Rs. 1,500.00 crore will be created as CGF. Out of up to Rs. 1,500.00 crore CGF, up to Rs. 1,000.00 crore will be created, maintained and managed by NABARD and the rest of up to Rs. 500.00 crore by NCDC.   DAC&FW will annually contribute on matching share basis to CGF created, maintained and managed by NABARD and NCDC each contributing equal amount to respective CGF without paying any other management cost both NABARD & NCDC for managing the Fund. (ii)The FPOs promoted and registered under Co-operative Societies Act will have option to avail CGF maintained and managed either by NBARD or NCDC. The FPOs promoted and registered under Companies Act can avail CGF maintained and managed by NABARD.
heading: 12.2 **Objective Of Cgf:**,12.3 Corpus Of Cgf:-
summary: The Credit Guarantee Fund (CGF) aims to provide a Credit Guarantee Cover to Eligible Lending Institutions (ELIs) to facilitate collateral-free credit to FPOs, reducing their lending risks. A dedicated fund of up to Rs. 1,500.00 crore will be created for the CGF, with NABARD and NCDC managing up to Rs. 1,000.00 crore and up to Rs. 500.00 crore, respectively. DAC&FW will annually contribute on a matching share basis to the CGF, with NABARD and NCDC each contributing an equal amount without incurring additional management costs. FPOs registered under the Co-operative Societies Act can choose to avail the CGF managed by either NABARD or NCDC, while those under the Companies Act can access the CGF managed by NABARD.

content: 13.1 Capacity building, training and skill development of CEOs/ BoDs and other  stakeholders identified by Nodal training institution, in consultation with DAC&FW, through transfer of technology, innovation is very essential for development of robust FPOs and for running the business activities successfully  on self-sustainable basis. The transfer of technology and innovation, inter alia, includes entire vertical and horizontal aspects of agricultural value chain, managerial aspect including accounting with focus on value addition, processing, and marketing. The subject matter of training will cover topics ranging from Organisational management/behaviour, crop husbandry, value addition, processing, marketing, trading, export, supply chain, grading, branding, packaging, accounting, auditing, compliance requirements, incubation, ICT & MIS as may be relevant for promotion of FPOs including  case studies in best practices if any.  13.2 The Bankers Institute of Rural Development (BIRD), Lucknow promoted by  NABARD is designated as Nodal Training Institution at central level for FPOs  promoted by NABARD and SFAC and other allowed/designated Implementing Agencies whether incorporated under Part IX A of Companies Act or registered under Co-operative Societies Act.
heading: 13.0 Training And Capacity Building For Promotion Of Fpos
summary: Training and capacity building are crucial for the development and sustainability of FPOs, involving CEOs, BoDs, and other stakeholders. This includes technology transfer, innovation, and various aspects of the agricultural value chain, as well as managerial skills such as accounting, processing, and marketing. The training will cover organizational management, crop husbandry, value addition, marketing, and compliance requirements, among other topics. The Bankers Institute of Rural Development (BIRD) in Lucknow is designated as the Nodal Training Institution at the central level for FPOs promoted by NABARD, SFAC, and other designated Implementing Agencies.

content: 15.1 In order to evaluate the performance of the scheme with reference to its  envisaged objectives, the mid-term (4th year) and end-term evaluation will be  done in terms of (i) No. of FPOs formed and registered; (ii) No. of farmers mobilized category-wise ; (iii) Quantum of Equity Grant provided and No. of FPOs covered;  (iv) Quantum of Credit Guarantee provided for credit linkages including volume of loan availed for working capital; (v) No. of training programmes conducted for capacity building and No. of persons trained and (vi) Business turnover of the FPOs.  15.2 DAC&FW will hire third party appropriate Consultant / Agency transparently for  undertaking the study as well as mid-term and end-term evaluation of the scheme. If it deems feasible and appropriate, DAC&FW may ask any of the Implementing Agencies to undertake the mid-term and end-term evaluation of the  scheme and evaluation report will be shared with DAC&FW and also among the other Implementing Agencies. Based on the suggestions and findings in the report, DAC&FW may modify the Operational guidelines. If exigency arises in the interest of the scheme, DAC&FW may at any time suitably modify the scheme to achieve the objective as envisaged in it.
heading: 15.0 Evaluation Of The Scheme
summary: The scheme's performance will be evaluated at the mid-term and end-term based on various factors including the number of FPOs formed, farmers mobilized, equity grant provided, credit guarantee, training programs conducted, and business turnover of the FPOs. The evaluation will be carried out by hiring a third-party consultant or agency, and the report will be shared with the relevant authorities.
